definition: to yield to one another/mutual accommodation
to yield/to permit/to let sb do sth/to have sb do sth/to make sb (feel sad etc)/by (indicates the agent in a passive clause, like 被[bei4])

sentences.english: Third, , uphold mutual understanding and mutual accommodation and peaceful settlement of disputes through dialogue and consultation.
sentences.chinese: 第三，互諒互讓，堅持對話協商和平解決爭議。

sentences.english: You need a give-and-take attitude to get along in this firm.
sentences.chinese: 要想在這個公司和同事處好，你需採取諒互讓的態度。

sentences.english: We can only settle this argument if there is a little give and take on both sides.
sentences.chinese: 只有雙方互諒互讓這個爭論才能解決。

sentences.english: Advocacy of the spirit of mutual understanding and mutual accommodation among successors.
sentences.chinese: 提倡繼承人之間互諒互讓的精神。

sentences.english: Employers and employees should deal with this matter in the spirit of mutual understanding and accommodation.
sentences.chinese: 勞資雙方要以互讓互諒的態度處理有關問題。
需採取互諒互讓的態度。

definition: highest common factor HCF/greatest common divisor GCD
to seek common ground, putting differences aside (idiom)
cross a river in the same boat (idiom); fig. having common interests/obliged to collaborate towards common goals
to be at the highest level of enlightenment (Buddhist expression)
lit. use others' strengths to make up for one's weak points (idiom from Mencius)/to use this in place of that/what you lose on the swings, you win on the roundabouts
to help the poor/almsgiving for the needy/to assist poor households or poor regions
fears of trouble in the rear (idiom); family worries (obstructing freedom of action)/worries about the future consequences/often in negative expressions, meaning "no worries about anything"
plethora of things to tackle/multitude of loose ends/very complicated/chaotic
to assess one's income and spend accordingly (idiom); to live within one's means/You can only spend what you earn.
take from the long to supplement the short (idiom)/to offset each other's deficiencies/to complement each other
benevolent heart and skillful execution (idiom, from Mencius); charitable in thought and deed
